Award.AwardTitle: Integrating Spatial and Temporal Models of Visual Attention

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
The human visual system uses attention to enhance the processing of information that is important for survival. For example, while driving on a highway, the sudden appearance of debris in the road will cause the visual system to rapidly orient towards the obstacle in order to allow avoidance. Attention orients in both space and time; it locks on to the location of the object, and also to the moment the object becomes visible. Currently, there is no well-accepted theory to describe how spatial and temporal factors interact in the control of attention. In order to create such a theory, Dr. Wyble will create a computational model of the spatial and temporal control of attention based on behavioral and EEG studies. This model will simulate the neural mechanisms that control attention and will thereby lead to a tighter coupling of theory and neuroscience.

The knowledge to be gained from this research will provide a simpler model of attention by combining existing theories from the spatial and temporal domains into a single framework. This framework will help us to understand why attention works in the way that it does, and also to understand why attention sometimes fails. The work may ultimately have applications in many areas, including transportation safety and visual prostheses for the blind. In addition, the work will include the development of a computer-programming tutorial aimed at increasing STEM training for students outside of traditional STEM fields.

POR.DRECONTENT:
When we perceive the world, the enormous amount of data that our senses take in must be filtered so that we can focus on the important information. This filtering is done by our attentional systems, which help each different sense, such as vision, hearing, and touch, to be efficient in processing information.  Without attention, the world would be a confusing, incomprehensible muddle of sights and sounds. Understanding how attention works is a key challenge for understanding the human mind, for building interfaces that people can use efficiently, and for cracking the hardest challenges of artificial intelligence.

Much of the work on attention has focused on vision, and there is an enormous number of theories and findings collected over many decades. The primary goal of this NSF project was to combine existing findings and ideas into a larger theoretical structure that explains how attention works.  A crucial ingredient in this process was to understand specifically how memory formation interacts with attention. Our central theory is that when we see something, our brain acts quickly to build a memory of that object. We hypothesize that building this new memory causes the brain to briefly pump the brakes, if you will, on attending to new information.  This is done to ensure that the current memory can be constructed without much interference from new pieces of information. 

This idea has the potential explain numerous findings in cognitive psychology that are often considered to be distinct effects. For example, the attentional cueing and attentional blink effects are considered as separate kinds of phenomena, each with a separate literature spanning decades and many hundreds of papers. The theory of attention-memory interaction that we explored in this grant provides a unified explanation for both of these findings, with the benefit of simplifying our understanding of how the brain attends. This project culminated in a key publication in a leading journal that described the unification of findings within a single theoretical framework. This was demonstrated using a computational model that explains a variety of empirical findings without many additional assumptions. The unified theory was also supported by a series of five peer-reviewed publications that detailed findings and involved in establishing this new theoretical basis. 

Another important outcome of this work was a discovery that memory formation can be extremely specific once people understand what they are looking for in a given situation.  Specifically, when people are searching for a particular kind of object, such as a letter, they find that object without being able to remember what the object was in the first place. In another example, we asked people to track a moving ball for up to a minute and then asked them to tell us what color the ball was. The first time we asked this question, subjects were unable to remember the ball’s color despite the fact that they had been staring at it for quite a while.

This phenomenon is similar to when we open the refrigerator and then forget why.  In the work we describe here, we found that these memory failures occur often when people have a very clear sense of what task they are performing, but are suddenly asked to perform the task in a different way. By finding a method to reproduce this slip-of-the-mind phenomenon in the laboratory, it will be possible to study and then predict under what situations people will fail to remember something that we would have otherwise thought of as obvious. More importantly, these findings provide a new direction in thinking about how memories should be constructed when designing artificial intelligence applications. Rather than remembering as many details as possible, remembering only the key details in a given situation could be a crucial optimization that enables higher levels of cognitive function. These ideas were explored in a peer-reviewed publication at an AI conference, and the rest of the experimental work was published in a series of six peer-reviewed publications. 

The project also had several broader impacts including the training of personnel at levels from undergraduate to graduate to postdoctoral.  The training provided students with technical skills in computational modelling, experiment design and data analysis, all of which are often critical for a modern career in research. For example one project that was initiated by this grant, and is run primarily by undergraduate students, uses virtual reality to study how attention works in 3 dimensions. Another impact was the development of a programming toolkit that makes it easier to use complex programming languages to run psychological experiments with a goal of streamlining the educational process for students in psychology.
